billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO COMMERCE, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND SMALL BUSINESS

title: Prohibits the transfer of liquor licenses from one owner to subsequent owners of the same establishment, bar or club
summary: Prohibits the transfer of liquor licenses from one owner to subsequent owners of the same establishment, bar or club; grants new owners a forty-five day temporary license in which time such new owner shall apply for a new liquor license pursuant to section sixty-four of the alcoholic beverage control law.
currentCommittee: COMMERCE, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND SMALL BUSINESS
fulltext:
S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         1279

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                   I N  S E N A T E

                                    January 6, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by  Sen.  DUANE  -- read twice and ordered printed, and when
         printed to be committed to the Committee on Commerce, Economic  Devel-
         opment and Small Business

       AN  ACT  to  amend  the  alcoholic  beverage control law, in relation to
         prohibiting the transfer of liquor licenses to new owners

         THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND  ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. Section 64 of the alcoholic beverage control law is amended
    2  by adding a new subdivision 4-a to read as follows:
    3    4-A.  NO  LICENSEE SHALL TRANSFER ANY INTEREST IN A LICENSE TO ANY NEW
    4  OWNER OF SUCH LICENSEE'S ESTABLISHMENT, BAR OR CLUB. SUCH LICENSE  SHALL
    5  TERMINATE  AT  THE  TIME OWNERSHIP OF THE PROPERTY IS TRANSFERRED TO THE
    6  NEW OWNER. SUCH NEW OWNER  SHALL  RECEIVE  A  FORTY-FIVE  DAY  TEMPORARY
    7  LICENSE  IN  WHICH  TIME SUCH PERSON SHALL APPLY FOR A PERMANENT LICENSE
    8  PURSUANT TO THE PROVISIONS OF THIS SECTION.
    9    S 2. This act shall take effect on the one hundred twentieth day after
   10  it shall have become a law.





        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.
                                                                  LBD00954-01-1
actClause: AN ACT to amend the alcoholic beverage control law, in relation to prohibiting the transfer of liquor licenses to new owners
